node.text: In this episode I discuss the materials used for pigments, the ancient Egyptian words for different colors, and what a remarkable text from Medinet Habu says about the transformative property of minerals. I also mention how you can learn how to read hieroglyphs!!!

node.text: The first installment in my IG Live series where I answer questions about ancient Egypt. In this episode I talk about Imhotep and Thutmose, two of the few named artists/architects from ancient Egypt, the Narmer Palette, Paleolithic rock art, composite perspective, the use of grids, and Minoan frescoes found in Avaris!

node.text:
Our home in Connecticut is a Greek revival from 1844, so we are quite interested in how more modern architecture relates to ancient models.  Here I stand before one of the homes of Harbi Ibrahim, who kindly granted his permission for me to talk about a mud-brick house that has been in his family for several generations.  These houses are survivals of earlier architectural forms and are increasingly rare in Upper Egypt, as traditional mud-brick constructions are replaced by fired brick and concrete.  With this video, I hope to help promote the cultural heritage of Egypt, both ancient and modern (much like my earlier post about zar amulets). One of the texts that I reference is a New Kingdom love poem, and I quote here from John's translation of the eighth poem of the first group in the Papyrus Harris cycle of love poetry: "The towered villa of my sister, its door in the middle of her demesne, its double door leaves open—The monkey is about to get out, and my sister is going ape.  Oh were I made her gateman; I would make her angry at me, so I could hear her voice, when she goes ape.  Through fear of her I shall become a child." Bekhen is the term for a towered structure, such as a temple pylon, here in the sense of a turreted villa.  The bekhen is the ancestor of the pyrgoi, the tower-augmented farmhouses so prominent in Egyptian documents of the Graeco-Roman period.  We also discuss this love poem in our YouTube video "Cat Humor in Ancient Egypt," and we are excited to announce that this week, we will be giving an "Egyptomania" house tour in our next YouTube video.
.
Shoes by @americanduchess 
.
#ancientegypt #historichome #antiquehome #egyptologist #1920s #1920sfashion #cloche #truevintage #historyofarchitecture #arthistory

node.text:
A preview of our YouTube video that will debut this afternoon (stay tuned for an announcement in stories when it is live!). We both wear 1930s vintage as we discuss and read passages from the Litany of Re.  If you haven't seen our videos introducing the Valley of the Kings, you may want to check those out.  In this video, we explain where the Litany of Re occurs, and its overall meaning as praise of the sun god Re, including the 75 forms in the Great Litany.  We focus on two addresses - Address 56 and 69.  Address 56 is to the "Great Cat," and here we give you an excerpt of our translation of Address 69 to the Netherworldly Baboon.  These addresses show how just a few epithets and phrases can conjure entire cycles of ancient Egyptian myths, and also how reading hieroglyphic texts is essential to interpreting iconography.  The Netherworldly Baboon form of Re is particularly interesting because Re is essentially worshipping himself.  In Egyptian beliefs, baboons typically adore the sun god at sunrise (this seems to be based on observations of baboons in nature), so to be a Netherwordly baboon is to predict the sun's rise, hence creating an endless cycle.  Preserving the solar cycle is at the heart of ancient Egyptian religion.  If you want to be able to follow along with some of the signs, you can review the basic signs @howtoreadhieroglyphs and our How to Read Hieroglyphs video on YouTube. 
.
My dress is from @missvioletvixen. 
.
#1930s #1930svintage #historichome #egyptologists #egyptology #ancientegypt #egyptianreligion #valleyofthekings #stylishacademic

node.text:
A short video from this past summer of the Vintage Egypt tour by @tribexdigital @itskhalifa__ featuring us at the Cataract Hotel, the Winter Palace, and the SS Sudan on the Nile (turn your phone for landscape). Modern tourism, owing much to the enterprise of the recently deceased Thomas Cook company, continued and updated a long history of foreign visitors to Egypt. During the Graeco-Roman Period, a number of interesting visitors immortalized themselves, none perhaps so directly as the visit of the imperial entourage under the emperor Hadrian, whose text crowd one another on the base of the northern colossus of Amenhotep III on the west bank of Thebes (the colossus of Memnon). Another visitor was the medical student and esoteric scholar Thessalus of Tralles. Journeying from Anatolia, in Alexandria he attempted—with disappointing results—to resurrect the magic of Pharaoh Necho II. Undeterred, he removed himself to Thebes, where, probably through incubation in the sanatorium at Deir el-Bahari, he tells us (or a pseudepigraphic attributed to him does) that the visual and aural manifestation of Asclepius-Imhotep revealed to the medical student important zodiacal and planetary associations of certain herbs. We cannot guarantee a divine manifestation, but one never knows—join us in June on our next vintage adventure (full details in bio link!).
.
#vintagetravel #vintageegypt #historichotel #truevintageootd #vintageadventure #vintagehotel #1920s #1920sfashion #1930s #1930sfashion

node.text: The Elkab expedition house we share with the Royal Museums of Art and History, Brussels, was designed by the British architect Somers Clarke, based to a large extent on the Byzantine era monastery of Saint Simeon on the west bank of Aswan.  Here, on the east bank of Aswan, we foxtrot beneath the central dome of the 1902 Restaurant at the @softiellegendoldcataract, its architecture inspired by the Cordoba mosque, itself only a bit more recent than the monastery.  The name of modern Aswan is the Arabic version of the Graeco-Roman Syene, deriving from the ancient Egyptian Swenet, the settlement on the east bank of the Nile.  Opposite the Old Cataract hotel is the island Elephantine, a Greek translation of Egyptian Abu, “elephant (island),” a reference to the site as an ivory emporium (not to some imaginary resemblance of granite boulders to bathing elephants, as occasionally suggested). On the west bank, beyond the southern tip of Elephantine, is Gebel Tingar, topped by an anvil-shaped rock that is covered with rock inscriptions. A stela of "King" Hatshepsut once stood atop the hill, describing the riches of the south that once flowed into Aswan, the "door of the south." Important officials in the area during the Old Kingdom bore the title “sealers of the god,” people responsible for the goods of religious significance such as ostrich feathers and leopard skins that flowed into the city.  In the early twentieth century Arthur Weigall noted that when one tired of the bands and gowns of the Aswan hotels, the spirits of the ancient carvaneers waited atop Gebel Tingar; alas the jazz bands have departed, but the Cataract Hotel remains, along with the spirits of Sabni, Harkhuf, and other ancient explorers. I wear a 1930s evening gown from @shopmorphew, John's 1930s dinner jacket is from @raysragtimehollywood (vest and trousers from @vintagevirtuosa). This amazing footage was captured by @hsn08 @tribexdigital.  If you want to join us on another amazing trip, Vintage Nile, takes place December 10-18 (link in bio or DM me to your email to be added to the mailing list).

node.text: The title of a book by Barbara Mertz (aka Elizabeth Peters, author of the Amelia Peabody novels), "Red Land, Black Land" is also the topic of my inaugural IGTV video. Here I stand—in the late afternoon after a very toasty day of work—at the boundary between the desert, the Red Land, and the cultivable land, the Black Land, adjacent to the Nile Valley. The geomorphological backdrop then leads me down a path about Egyptian kingship and the conflict between Horus and Seth.  In the genealogy of the Heliopolitan Ennead (the nine deities who represent the totality of the Egyptian differentiation of one into many balanced pairs, the essence of Egyptian creation), Geb and Nut give birth to the siblings Osiris, Isis, Seth, and Nephthys.  At some point during Osiris' reign over Egypt as divine king, Seth murders him In later versions, the fratricide becomes dismemberment as Seth strews pieces of Osiris' corpse throughout Egypt.  The roots of this mythic cycle go back into the Pyramid Texts, but the blow-by-blow recording of events is only found in Greek sources two thousand years later, thus some of the episodes are almost certainly later developments. Despite Seth's role in the murder of Osiris, Seth is not evil personified—to find out who fills that role in Egyptian religion, stay tuned through the end of this video.

node.text:
The best possible setting to display pieces from the phenomenal collection of @azzafahmy: standing on the deck of the Steamship Sudan, with the Ptolemaic temple of Kom Ombo in the background. I wear a 1970s Bill Gill gown (from @zeusvintage) and the @azzafahmy gold and silver multi-row broad collar and Tut Ring. Most ancient Egyptian temples used an axial plan, meaning that the sanctuary was located along the same axis as the entrance pylons. Most temples have a secondary internal axis perpendicular to the main axis.  Begun under Ptolemy VI and oriented perpendicular to the Nile, the temple of Kom Ombo is unusual in having dual, parallel axes, since it is dedicated to two deities: Horus and the Elder and Sobek. Horus received the northern processional route, while the crocodile god has the southern. Decoration was mostly complete by the time of Ptolemy VIII, with outer portions of the temple complex finished by Ptolemy XII, Nero, and Vespasian.  In the open-air solar temples of Amarna, likely based on Heliopolitan prototypes, the Egyptians innovated, placing off-set walls in front of the sanctuary that screened the rituals that occurred in the inner sanctum.  Whether in a dark, small chamber, or beneath the rays of the sun, the Egyptians believed that the priests, as they censed, libated, offered food, and sang hymns, were maintaining the balance of the cosmos.  Proper performance of rituals meant the continuation of maat, and a never-ending solar cycle.
.
#egyptologist #ancientegypt #komombo #egyptiantemple #egyptianreligion #1970svintage #egyptianrevival #azzafahmy

node.text:
Vignettes from @jazzagelawnparty celebrating 1920s fashion and the re-creation of jazz age dance (from careful observation of period movies). As Arthur Weigall long ago pointed out, in spite of the modern world's fixation on the mortuary customs of the ancient Egyptians and belief that they were a "gloomy" people, texts and images reveal that the frequency and nature of their celebrations probably eclipsed most others prior to the high Roman Empire.  In other words, the ancient Egyptians liked to party!  Even at remote desert sites, we have evidence of celebrations, especially those involving the return of the solar eye goddess (like Hathor). A common formula for a suitably party-going Egyptian official recorded on a number of monuments from the Middle Kingdom and New Kingdom is "The man of the festival, beloved of myrrh, companion of the holiday." Other evocative passages include "Lay on myrrh, rub on oil, let one celebrate a holiday!" While you can't tell from the videos, I am wearing here the perfect 1920s version of ancient myrrh: @penhaligons_london "Juniper Sling."
.
The green Hungarian embroidery dress is from @tootsvintage (paired a step-in from @demetravintage with a hat from @amandasatticvintage) and the pink and orange chiffon dresses are from @shopmorphew (still available!) paired with a cloche from @grevi1875.  Everything John is wearing other than his spectacular duplex from @blakesbyhats is 1920s (and that includes his shoes)! 
.
Thanks to @vpvisuals for the dance video!
.
#flapperfashion #charleston #greatgatsby #1920s #mensvintage #jazzage #lawnparty #1920sfashion #truevintage #vintagestyle

node.text:
A poolside portrait by the amazing @vizzzuals (I love her painterly style). The ancient Egyptian connection today is not in our late 1920s and early 1930s garb or the coordinating blue color, but a book we wrote together: a translation of the texts in the New Kingdom tombs in the Valley of the Kings--the Ancient Egyptian Netherworld Books.  The topic of this Friday's "Ancient Egypt Live" at 4pm will be the Netherworld Books and funerary texts.  What do you want to know about ancient Egyptian beliefs about the afterlife?
.
The Netherworld Books describe the twelve-hour journey of Re through the Netherworld, each hour a unit both of space and time.  In the bottom registers of the tenth hour of the Book of the Hidden Chamber and the ninth hour of the Book of Gates are large bodies of water in which float drowned individuals.  While one might assume that these are the damned, they are actually blessed dead.  In the tenth hour of the Book of the Hidden Chamber, the god Horus looks after the drowned, saying: "May you go forth into the floodwaters.  May you descend into the flowing water.  May you be immersed in the Great Flood.  May you moor at the banks.  Your limbs shall not rot.  Your flesh shall not putrefy.  Power be to you in your water.  May you breathe that which I have commanded for you.  You are those who are within Nun, the drowned who are in his following. May life belong to your ba-souls." The Egyptians believed that mummification was essential to preserving the corpse and arresting the process of decay, but it is fascinating that people who drowned could attain the same result, because they were in contact with the primordial waters of Nun.
.
#egyptologists #ancientegypt #vintagestyle #truevintage #mensvintage #1920s #1930s #vintageswimwear #vintageportrait

node.text:
Having a blast @twahotel from a shoot last summer with @ninagalicheva.nyc and makeup by @myvintageloveblog.  The spy-themed music resonates with what we know about military intelligence in ancient Egypt.  In a Nubian battle text of Seti I, the pharaoh delays his own decision so that he might "learn their (the enemies') plans thoroughly." Ramesses II demonstrated the dangers of reacting on the basis of unsubstantiated intelligence.  During its march toward the city of Kadesh, the Egyptian army captured two apparent Bedouin men, who reported to Ramesses II that the Hittites were far to the north.  Only after the Hittite chariotry had ambushed part of the Egyptian army did Ramesses learn that the captured men were spies in Hittite employ, sent to provide false information. Egyptian scouts employed in the Levantine portions of their empire were called meher, and were expected to memorize extensive information about the region, including any geographical features that might be important when planning a military expedition--the location of cities, towns, roads connecting them, as well as the topography of each area.  Mounted scouts were essential to provide intelligence and monitor rapidly changing situations. 
.
1960s Courrèges dress from @shopmorphew, tights from @wildfellhall; monokini by @rudigernreich; Courrèges cat suit from @jamesveloria.
.
This shoot appeared in print @thecapmag Winter 2020.
.
#theavengers #musictospyby #1960s #courrèges #courreges #1960sfashion #modfashion #1960sdress

node.text:
Wearing a ca. 1925 Bradley Knitting Company swimsuit with koi fish from @fabgabs (swipe for an advertisement featuring this very suit - image from the blog of @thevintagetraveler). The ancient Egyptians might find a great deal of symbolism in a red swimsuit decorated with a fish.  A well-read Egyptian of the Ramesside Period might recall the poem that survives in the Cairo Love Songs, written over an erased copy of the Instruction of Amenemhat.  A girl says that she will go swimming in a fine linen tunic covered in oil, as from a festival, in order to emerge from the water holding a red fish, the tilapia.  The tilapia fish can symbolize rebirth (see the caption to my reels where I wear the swimsuit). Based on the evidence from several ancient texts, we know that scenes of fishing and fowling in Egyptian tombs may relate to the concept of the migrating soul manifesting as a fish by night and a bird by day.  Within the realm of color imagery, the sun may have different hues for certain times of the day, these color components being red, green, blue, and white.  Together, these colors reference the concept of the sun as "multi-colored" and "scintillating," described by the Egyptians with the word tjehen.  The colors can also  manifest as minerals, which the Egyptians could then manipulate in order to capture the power of the sun: carnelian, lapis lazuli, turquoise, and alabaster.  The solar disk in the morning, emerging from the womb of its cosmic mother may be described in the Book of Nut as "swimming in its redness." 
.
Thanks to @alberto.urcia for his help with this shoot. 
.
#1920s #vintageswimsuit #1920sstyle #truevintage #parasol #vintageswimwear #vintagelove #fish #ancientegypt #egyptologist

node.text:
A medley of clips ascending and descending the stairways on the @steamshipsudan.  Ancient Egyptian vessels of the pharaonic era did not have multiple decks, although they do show stairs allowing access to the roofs of deck structures.  In some depictions, especially of late Old Kingdom through Middle Kingdom date, we see the crew manipulating the mast and the lines from the tops of such structures.  Houses in ancient Egypt, like the tightly-packed structures at Deir el-Medina, had stairs leading to the roof, and some buildings would have had multiple stories, as well as roof-top rooms for use in warmer weather.  We see a similar adaptation of domestic architecture in temples with roof-top shrines, such as the famous Hathor and Osiris chapels at Dendera.  The stairwells of Ptolemaic temples (again Dendera and Edfu offer excellent examples) are decorated with reliefs that show priests ascending the steps, equipped for ritual celebrations.  At Khonsu Temple in Karnak, priests visiting the roof of the temple left numerous graffiti, including foot-prints; at least some of those priests may have been celebrating rituals associated with the leg of Osiris (body parts of the dismembered and reassembled god of regeneration were worshipped at various places throughout Egypt, especially during the Graeco-Roman period).
.
Outfits include a 1930s Lanvin set from @wildfellhall; a 1930s evening dress from @allybirdvintage; pajamas from @shopmorphew; and a chiffon 1920s dress from @myvintageloveblog.
.
#vintagetravel #artdeco #steamshipsudan #vintagefashion #truevintage #vintagelove #vintageglamour

node.text:
Embodying the roaring 20s in a gold flapper dress (from @shopmorphew). In this reel, I also channel a number of Roman Period gilded mummy cartonnages, like British Museum EA 69020 and Cairo CG 33216, in which the clothing and body of the deceased are gilded, like the golden skin of the goddess Hathor, the face of the sun.  The girl in the Cairo example even wears a diadem, like my rhinestone encrusted 1920s headpiece (from @littletreasuresvintage2). A diadem can also represent the concept of "justification" in the Underworld and a laurel wreath even appears as a sign in some of the last hieroglyphic inscriptions.  Roman period coffins and cartonnages frequently depict the deceased holding a garland of the roses of Isis (what the protagonist Lucius in the Roman novella The Golden Ass has to eat from the Isis procession to transform from a donkey back to a man), and in the other hand a cup or chalice representing the water of Osiris.  My nineteenth century champagne glass filled with water serves that function here.  Osiris often appears as a mummy, but for the Egyptians, most religious imagery evokes a process.  For that reason, Osiris can be seen as the source of the Nile, his putrefaction or efflux (rudju), being a symbol of the rising waters.  Sometimes what is otherwise water held by the deceased is represented with a red color, probably being transformed into the wine of Dionysus with whom Osiris may be equated.
.
#1920s #flapperfashion #greatgatsby #roaring20s #historichome #antiquefurniture #empirefurniture #antiqueglassware #antiquehome

node.text:
A portrait by @vpvisuals at the entrance to the court of the main house @craneestate_trustees, wearing a floral 1930s dress and a broad-brimmed 1930s hat (with the label Ceceil Clarke from @_bustles2boho_). Behind me is a carved representation of an enormous bowl of fruit and flowers.  This continues the appearance of ceramic forms in stone, already attested in Graeco-Roman architecture (like the enormous urn atop the tomb of Aretas IV at Petra), combined with the imagery of agricultural bounty often seen in the form of the cornucopia.  Set in front of a home, this symbolizes welcome for visitors.  In ancient Egypt, we have evidence for similar demonstrations of offering wealth at temples.  In Tutankhamun's scenes of the Opet Festival, the entrance to Luxor Temple is marked by numerous altars heaped with food surrounded by wine amphorae, topped by burning bowls of incense.  A demonstration of massive food offerings for a deity
and royal donations of food to dependents all comes together in the enormous courts of square altars heaped--apparently daily--with similar repasts in temples of Aten at Akhet-Aten (modern Amarna). Through application of the concept of "reversion of offerings," gods may take what they need, and humans subsequently get what they require from the same offerings.  Religious compositions, like the Coffin Texts and the Netherworld Books, make reference to how a person who possesses knowledge eats from the food of a god in a particular temple, suggesting that people might derive nourishment from divine offerings both while they are alive and after they are dead.
.
Shoes @remixvintageshoes 
.
#1930s #1930sdress #1930sfashion #roaringtwentieslawnparty #craneestate #vintageportrait #vintagehat #truevintage #ancientegypt #egyptologist

node.text:
Another spectacular collaboration with @genuinegentleman, where John and I both wear 1920s summer attire (the pink chiffon dress I wear is still available @shopmorphew). The ancient Egyptians loved gardens, and wealthy people constructed their villas to contain gardens surrounding a pool (in the shape of a hieroglyph for pool!). But gardens are not simply associated with homes.  The great stone temples of Egypt are ultimately models of the cosmos, their enormous columns in the form of plants that grew on the banks of the Nile (papyrus, lotus, and palms). From images, archaeological evidence, and inscriptions, we know that the plant life associated with temples did not stop at the outside of the stone structures.  Most temples were surrounded by landscaped gardens, so a priest leaving the inner portion of the temple would walk out of a dark room into a space that evoked the early plant life emerging from the receding waters of chaos at the beginning of time.  Eventually, the priest or priestess would emerge from the first court and enter an ordered and well manicured world.  In an inscription on the 18th Dynasty temple at Medinet Habu, Ramesses III recorded that he had incorporated the earlier structure into the garden area in front of his mortuary temple. 
.
Event: @roaringtwentieslawnparty
Location: @craneestate_trustees
.

node.text:
I'm thrilled to be partnering with @varsitytutors again to explore what it was like to grow up in Ancient Egypt.  The mummies, pharaohs, and pyramid builders of Ancient Egypt were all children once. And believe it or not, their childhoods were in some ways similar to our own! Join me on August 26 at 7PM EST to learn what games Ancient Egyptian children played, what clothing and hairstyles were popular, how they interacted with their pets, and much more.  This free lecture is geared for 3rd to 7th graders, but if you are interested in learning more about an often overlooked aspect of ancient Egypt, I think this will be enjoyable for all!
.
In the lecture, I will discuss what sorts of pets the ancient Egyptians had, especially dogs.  Cats were also popular pets, and were normally called miu "cat," whereas dogs received names like people.  Here, with one of our two basenji dogs, Narmer, I study two images of children from ancient Egypt (which I will discuss in more detail) - Nakht and his family fishing and fowling in the marshes, and Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and their daughters in the palace.  The curly-tailed basenji breed was popular in ancient Egypt, but they also had a variety of hound breeds.  More exotic pets are also known, from gazelles to even Ramesses II's pet lion that accompanied him in battle!  Join me on August 26th for a free lecture to learn more!
.

node.text:
Walking through the Italian Gardens of Castle Hill wearing a dress ca. 1910-1915 (available from @shopmorphew) in another amazing collaboration with @genuinegentleman.  The juxtaposition of the white crochet and lace with the light blue embroidery is reminiscent of Josiah Wedgwood's Jasperware that often replicated classical motifs.  Wedgwood could not have known that during the reign of Amunhotep III (1390-1352 BCE), a favorite ceramic style was cream-slipped or marl jars with blue-painted motifs that often featured plant designs. running horses, girls in papyrus skiffs, and calves frolicking in the marshes.  Applied decoration could include sculpted gazelles or the head of Hathor (thus some of the same imagery we discuss in the previous reel, featuring red 20s swimwear). The blue paint of the late 18th Dynasty vessels is remarkable for possibly being a synthetic pigment, "cobalt blue," made "through precipitation from a hydrous solution of alum and a soluble cobalt compound with ammonium or sodium carbonate as precipitants." (D. Arnold and J. Bourriau, An Introduction to Ancient Egyptian Pottery, p. 101). As Colin Hope has suggested, the ancient Egyptians sourced their alum from Dakhla and Kharga oases.  Far flung resources to create art extended to ancient Egyptian gardens as well.  The "Botanical Garden" chamber of Thutmose III at Karnak Temple shows how plants from all over the Middle East were collected to create a living work of art, much like the Italian Gardens through which I stroll. 
.
Location: @craneestate_trustees
Event: @roaringtwentieslawnparty
.
#edwardianfashion #roaringtwentieslawnparty #craneestate #castlehill #edwardiandress #italiangarden #wedgwood #neoclassical #ancientceramics #ancientpottery

node.text:
Continuing the swimsuit theme, bejeweled by @azzafahmy I wear a 30s Jantzen two-piece from @diggerodellvintage on the balcony of our favorite room at the @sofitellegendoldcataract. This is at twilight, a period for which the ancient Egyptians had several terms (one being akhekhou), when the sun still shines low on the horizon of the high desert, the Nile Valley basking in the afterglow. Behind me is Elephantine island, ancient Abu, and in the distance to the west (just to the left of my head) is Gebel Agg. A large boulder there has attracted many rock inscriptions, and at some point a dry stone enclosure was set up, with some free standing monuments, including a stela of  Hatshepsut mentioning trade from the far south. A quarry road snakes up past the site, and a route to the far south begins here as well, at the traditional border of Egypt. As A.E.P. Weigall once wrote: "When the amusements of the luxurious hotels have given out, and the solemnity of the ancient ruins has begun to pall, the spirits of Harkhuf and Sabna, of the captains and caravan-conductors, are always to be found waiting on the breezy hill-tops behond the island of Elephantine, at the head of the Nubian highway.”
.
#azzafahmy #oldcataract #vintagetravel #ancientegypt #vintageswimwear #truevintage #vintagestyle #elephantine #aswan #thisisegypt
